This has to one of the worst games published by the Avalon Hill game company. Berg is often viewed as a great designer and when I bought this I had many of his games and I viewed them extremely positive. Unfortunately this game was not typical of the other games he designed that I purchased. The rules are so poorly presented that in some respects it is virtually unplayable without major inhouse modifications. Even with these house rule change the game is a mess. It was an extreme task to learn, relearn, modify and attempt to play. This should not happen in ones hobby that should be a fun engaging activity. And relaxing past time.This was a complete exercise in futility. A waste of time, patience and money. Thankfully I have very few games like this in my collection. For me this was a one off for Berg as he went on to produce some great games such as the MOI series.

Created during the last days of Monarch Avalon Hill's existence, Geronimo's rules suffer from a lack of organization and coherence. It's obvious that the game was rushed out and an attempt at decent editing was skipped, which is too bad because a large-scale examination of the entirety of the Indian Wars in the American West is unique to wargaming. The photo of Berg wearing a native headdress, and bears a bit of testament to his hubris. Still, Geronimo's components are good, and with a little work, an experienced gamer could make the game into a fun experience. It's interesting that this game was an influence on Toppen's Navajo Wars and Commancheria.

On the surface this should be a solid game. The components are good and even somewhat better then typical for 1995. The game itself is a complete miss. The rules are very unclear and will take a huge investment in time to comprehend. Playing the game will help a bit but vast time and effort will be exhausted in this process. In the end due to the poorly written rules and cumbersome mechanics the game become tedious and not worth the effort. Played with several opponents who typically gave up play after a few turns. Most found the topic a draw but the game itself a complete bore due to the constant rule misinterpretations and ambiguities. Most found the process of flipping through the rule book a complete drain and game downer. It probably took me 5-6 hours to go through the rules and an equal amount of time to fumble through game play. In the end this type of investment in time is not worth it it for a lack lustre game that was exhaustive to learn and play. Shame because I have owned this game for years and finally had the time and other players needed for game play and it turned in to a complete bust.

A unique theme portraying the expansion of the settlers towards the West coast and the effects on the native Indian population. Sadly, this game has been under rated. The hard map depicts the central and western US states, the counters represent: the Indian tribes of the era, generals, artillery, settlements, rail expansion, weather, statehood and even Mormon columns. The rule book is clear and straightforward. After one game turn the players get the feeling of the play. All players are handling Indian tribes apart from one who will be the US. On the next game turn all players switch tribes and another one becomes the US player. The US player earns points from winning battles, putting tribes on reservation and for completing the rail expansion. The Indian players win points by maintaining their independence and blocking further expansion. The Indian players have an easy task if it wasn't for the inter-tribal differences and hostilities. Indian players should focus on earning points and not battling each other, after all their main enemy is the US. Each player should also keep note that he will get to be the US at least once on each game play; previews policies might backfire when his turn comes up. The game concept is an opportunity to witness history unfolding before your eyes and realize the cruel reality that befall on the natives. An excellent simulation that wargamers will not regret owning it.

Los EE.UU. - los conflictos de la India, un período trágico de la historia.

Cada turno, los jugadores son asignados al azar un lado para jugar - ya sea tribus indias o los EE.UU. Sólo un jugador representa los EE.UU. cada turno, mientras que los otros jugadores tienen cada uno un número de tribus indias bajo su control. jugadores de la India llegan a seleccionar uno o dos de sus tribus activos, pero el resto se reparten al azar ellos. Por lo general hay tribus indias más disponibles de lo que están activos en cada turno, pero los jugadores no saben realmente cuáles son inactivos. Esto puede ser perturbador para el jugador EE.UU. ya que debe decidir dónde desplegar sus limitados tropas y columnas.

Todos los jugadores compiten para ganar puntos de victoria. El jugador de EE.UU. se enfrenta a la tarea de la construcción de suficientes recursos (acuerdos, ciudades, ferrocarriles, minas, etc.) para mantener los estados existentes y convertir los territorios en estados. Los jugadores de la India desempeñan el papel de la guerrilla para ganar puntos de victoria, pero también puede negar recursos para el jugador EE.UU.. Sin embargo, se debe tener mucho cuidado de no sufrir demasiadas bajas, ya que esto podría causar su tribu para ir en reserva o se extinguen, que cuesta muy caro en el reproductor de puntos de victoria.
